title: Trista and Ryan Sutter's 2 Kids Look All Grown Up on the First Day of Junior and Senior Year
description: Trista and Ryan Sutter's two kids look all grown up on their first day of junior and senior year. The proud mom wrote that the time "just goes too fast" in her caption.
content:
Trista and Ryan Sutter's kids are (almost) all grown up!

The mom of two, 52, shared an emotional video on Instagram on Thursday, Aug. 14 as she celebrated her daughter Blakeley's first day of junior year and her son Maxwell's first day of senior year. Trista included photos of her kids' first days of school throughout the year, starting in kindergarten and ending with a sweet clip of the two together.

"It just goes too fast. 🥹," Trista wrote in her caption. "Junior year for Blakesley Grace and the last, first day for our senior (what?!!! 😭), Maxwell Alston." "I love you both to the moon and back to the moon and back to the moon and back to infinity and beyond and I cannot wait to see what this year has in store for you both (but I’m putting in a request for time to slow down. 🙏🏼)," she said.

Trista and her husband Ryan got engaged in 2003 during the finale episode of Trista's Bachelorette season. They went on to welcome son Maxwell in 2007 and daughter Blakeley in 2009.

Last August, the former star told her followers that some parents demonstrate her "biggest pet peeve" while supporting their kids at sporting events .

As she revealed that her son Max has hockey games scheduled all weekend, and she will spend the Labor Day holiday cheering him on from the bleachers, Trista took the opportunity to share something that bothers her about other parents at kids' sports events.

"One of my biggest pet peeves is each game there's a home team and an away team," Trista explained. "I always sit on whichever team our team is on. So if they're the home team for that game I sit on the home side, if they're the away team then I sit on the away side."

"Seems easy, right?" the mom-of-two said, before venting about how not every parent shares this logic.

"But there are parents that just don't feel the same and they sit on whatever side they want, and it drives me nuts," Trista continued. "I'm like, 'Why can't you sit on your team's side?'"

"Does this drive anyone else crazy, or am I just loopy and have nothing else better to do?" she said with a laugh, adding a question box for her followers to respond.

That previous April, Trista shared a carousel of images on Easter Sunday , in which she posed alongside her family of four. In other images, the couple could be seen with extended family members at a church service, and in one, just Trista and Ryan posed for a selfie in the sun.

"Thankful for the gifts of life and love, family near and far, friends new and old, and moments of connection and joy," Trista captioned the images. "Happy Easter!"
summary: Trista and Ryan Sutter's two children, Blakeley and Maxwell, are almost all grown up. The mother-of-two shared an emotional video on Instagram as she celebrated her children's first day of junior year and senior year respectively. She also shared her frustrations about other parents who sit on different sides during sports events. The couple got engaged in 2003 and welcomed their children in 2007.
shortSummary: Trista and Ryan Sutter's children are nearly grown up, celebrating their first days in junior and senior years, while addressing social media etiquette.

The Bachelorette alum, 51, revealed in an Instagram post on Friday, Nov. 15 that she had been working on the third season of Special Forces: World’s Toughest Test in May — around the same time her husband, Ryan Sutter, shared social media posts that sparked concerns about their relationship. “Was it a divorce/nervous breakdown/mid-life crisis/death/trial separation back in May?! The fan response prompted Ryan, 50, to later clarify that Trista was “fine” and that they, as a couple, were “great.” He added at the time, “Trista is at a place in life where she is searching a bit. An opportunity presented itself that may help her on that quest. With her family’s support, she has taken it. Part of that process means that she is temporarily inaccessible to us. I miss her. Ryan Sutter Says He Still Can't Watch Wife Trista's Season of The Bachelorette — 17 Years Later The father of two says it's "always been really uncomfortable for me" By Aurelie Corinthios Published on July 7, 2020 10:26AM EDT Almost two decades later, Ryan Sutter still hasn't been able to watch his love story with wife Trista unfold on The Bachelorette. Fresh off of being dumped by the original Bachelor Alex Michel, Trista (then Trista Rehn) became the first Bachelorette in 2003. It was there that she met and fell in love with Ryan, a firefighter. The two got married in a televised ceremony in December 2003. Seventeen years later, they're still together and live in Colorado with their son Max, 12, and daughter Blakesley, 11. After Monday's episode of ABC's retrospective series, The Bachelor: The Greatest Seasons — Ever!, looked back on their journey, the couple made a virtual appearance on Good Morning America on Tuesday. Eugene Gologursky/Getty The Bachelor and Bachelorette Couples — Who Made Their Love Last? Trista, 47, said she remains "very, very, very grateful" that Michel didn't choose her. But despite their success story, Ryan, 45, admitted he still can't watch his wife's season of the show. "Always been really uncomfortable for me," he said. "First of all, I don't like watching myself on television. I also don't like watching my wife kiss other guys on TV, so." The couple also revealed that their kids are starting to get an inkling of who their parents are. "I remember Blakesley, one time, she was like, 'Are we famous?'" Ryan recalled. "And you're trying to explain to her that people know who you are, but we're not really famous." As for the future of the franchise? Both are looking forward to Clare Crawley's upcoming season of The Bachelorette, followed by Matt James' debut as the first black Bachelor. "I'm really excited," Trista said. "It's about time. I am in full support of more diversity in The Bachelor and The Bachelorette — the whole franchise." And Crawley is the "perfect lead," she added. "There are still people out there who want to jump to judgment about why a woman would do this," she said. "I think that Clare is the perfect lead because she's really strong an intelligent, and she's going to fight for what she deserves." The Bachelor: The Greatest Seasons — Ever! returns July 20 at 8 p.m. ET on ABC. Read more: Entertainment TV Reality TV

argos_summary: Trista Sutter, the former Bachelorette, shared an emotional Instagram video celebrating her daughter Blakeley's first day of junior year and her son Maxwell's senior year, reflecting on how fast time passes. She also posted about her biggest pet peeve at kids‑sports events—parents not sitting on their team’s side—and clarified rumors that she had been distant in 2024, saying her absence was due to filming the third season of Special Forces: World’s Toughest Test. The couple, who married after their 2003 Bachelorette finale, have two teens and recently celebrated Easter together. Sutter’s posts highlight her gratitude for family and her desire to slow down the whirlwind of her children’s growing up.
